newsitem.title: CHINA: China sees '97 onshore oil investment at $10.8 bln.
newsitem.headline: China sees '97 onshore oil investment at $10.8 bln.

text.p: China is expected to invest nearly 90 billion yuan ($10.8 billion) on onshore oil exploration and development this year, a senior official of China National Petroleum Corp (CNPC) said on Wednesday.
"We are likely to spend about 70 billion yuan in developing our oilfields this year," CNPC vice president Zeng Xingqiu told Reuters in an interview.
The state-run oil producer would spend an additional 20 billion yuan on exploration, he said.
Most of the money would be from internal funds while some would be from bank borrowings.

Zeng said the company aims to stabilise output at its big Daqing field in northeast China at around 50 million tonnes per year. It hopes to boost production at its Shengli field in the east to 40 million tonnes from about 30 million tonnes currently.
The official said this would be done by using more advanced drilling technology and deeper drilling at the Shengli field.
China's crude output from its Daqing and Shengli oilfields have been stagnating in recent years.
Zeng also said CNPC aims to increase production from the Tarim Basin in the far western region of Xinjiang to five million tonnes from 4.5 million tonnes last year. ($1 = 8.3 yuan)
